subject: AI and future jobs
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread is dominated by a debate over AI's impact on the labor market, polarizing between a doomer outlook of widespread job loss, wage stagnation, and societal restructuring (UBI, depopulation) versus a more optimistic view of increased productivity and new job creation. There's a strong undercurrent of conspiracy theories, accusations of 'shilling' for AI companies, and general nihilism regarding the future for younger generations.
top_quote: Increased productivity =/= increased jobs. Imagine you own a factory with 100 employees who can each make 100 widgets a day for a total of 10,000 widgets. Let's say a new machine is created that allows each employee to make 1000 widgets a day instead. Let's say that the maintenance and operation of these machines will require 10 additional employees. The naive would assume that you would hire 10 new employees to handle the machines and make 100,000 widgets a day for a net gain of 10 jobs. But this is only the case if you can actually sell 100,000 widgets. If demand is already saturated and cannot be increased by lowering prices then it makes more sense to simply keep prices high and fire 90 of your employees and hire 10 people to run the machines for a net loss of 80 jobs. You now have 20 employees making the same 10,000 widgets. The idea of technological unemployment ultimately leading to new jobs is a boomer meme from an era when the world was so poor and starved of basic goods that there was essentially unlimited demand as long as you could keep decreasing prices. That era is long over.
image_analysis: The image displays a screenshot of a headline stating, "AI Expert Warns 99% of Workers Will Lose Jobs by 2030," reinforcing the thread's predominant fear-based narrative about AI-driven unemployment.

subject: why are crypto dieded?
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The prevailing sentiment is that retail crypto is 'dead' due to market oversaturation, the absence of genuinely new narratives for growth (replaced by VC extraction), and widespread retail skepticism from past losses. While some envision future institutional adoption, current macro realities and competition from other forms of gambling further diminish individual investor interest.
top_quote:
Bull runs grow from seeds.
The seed is a new narrative that a small group of users actually think is a big deal. They make 10x. They tell their friends. Their friends make 5x. They tell their friends that there is this actual new thing and people are making a ton of money out of it.
So to have a bullrun you need:
1) New narratives that
2) People actually believe in, that
3) Launch at a low enough cap for early users to make money off.

The current meta is just mass VC extraction events launching down-only stale narratives (another L1 lmao) at $10B FDV.
No retail makes any money so there is no group of organic shills, so there is no momentum.

Couple that with ever increasing retail skepticism as alts underperform year after year, and the result is that we will basically need literally useful, adopted apps launching at low caps before there's any chance of a bullrun again.
